member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2NipalsAlgorithm
member.summary: Class PLS2NipalsAlgorithm encapsulates the Nonlinear Iterative PArtial Least Squares (NIPALS) algorithm for computing partial least squares regression components.
member.remarks: During the calculation the following model for PredictorMatrix (independent variable values) is is formed: PredictorMatrix = TP' + Xg where g is the number of components specified for the model. T is called the scores matrix (the columns of T are the scores), and P is called the loadings matrix. The matrix Xg is called the residual matrix for PredictorMatrix. A corresponding model for ResponseMatrix (dependent variable values) is formed: ResponseMatrix = UQ' + Yg U is the scores matrix for ResponseMatrix, Q the loading matrix for ResponseMatrix, and Yg is the residual matrix for ResponseMatrix.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2NipalsAlgorithm.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a PLS2NipalsAlgorithm instance;

member.summary: Whether the most recent calculation was successful.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2NipalsAlgorithm.Message
member.summary: Gets any message that may have been generated by the algorithm. For example, if the calculation is unsuccessful, the message indicates the reason.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2NipalsAlgorithm.PredictorMean
member.summary: Gets the vector of means for the predictor variables.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2NipalsAlgorithm.ResponseMean
member.summary: Gets the vector of means for the response variables.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2NipalsAlgorithm.Coefficients
member.summary:
Gets the regression coefficients matrix, B, for the PLS2 calculation. B satisifies the relationship ResponseVector = XB + E.
where X and ResponseVector are respectively, the centered independent and dependent variables values, and EE is a noise term for the model.
member.remarks:
The coeffient matrix, B, can be used for prediction as follows:
Let yhat(z) be the predicted value for the independet variable value z, xbar the mean of the PredictorMatrix variables and ybar the mean of ResponseVector variables. Then yhat(z) = ybar + (z - xbar)B.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm
member.summary: Class PLS2SimplsAlgorithm encapsulates the Straightforward IMplementation of Partial Least Squares, or SIMPLS, algorithm (de Jong, 1993) for computing partial least squares regression components.
member.remarks:
The SIMPLS is used to find a predictive linear model of the form Y = XB, where Y is a matrix of response variables, X is a matrix of predictor variables, and B is the matrix of regression coefficients. This is achieved by compressing the predictor data matrix X = [x1, x2,..., xp] that contains the p values of n samples, into a set of c latent variable or factor scores T = [t1, t2,...,tc]
These factor scores are then used to fit a set of n observations to m response variables Y = [y1, y2,...,ym]
The relationship between the X and T is T = XR, where R is the matrix of predictor weights. Factor scores U and weights Q for the response variable Y are also computed and satisfy U = Y0Q, where Y0 is the matrix of centered response data.
The algorithm requires the computation of a dominant eigenvector at each iteration. The iterative Power Method is used to calculate this eigenvector and the maximum number of iterations and convergance tolerance may be specified for instances of this class through either through the contructor or properties.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an PLS2SimplsAlgorithm instance. The maximum number of iterations and convergence tolerance used in the power method to compute the dominant eigenvector at each iteration of the SIMPLS algorithm are set to their default values.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs an instance of the PLS2SimplsAlgorithm class with the specified values for the maximum number of iterations and tolerance to be used in the power method algorithm used for computing dominant eigenvectors.
member.remarks: The power method converges if changes in the normalized eigenvector, with respect to the infinity norm, is less than the specified tolerance.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.DefaultMaxPowerIteration
member.summary: Gets and sets the default value for the maximum number of iterations to be performed when use the power method for computing dominant eigenvectors and eigenvalues needed by the SIMPLS algorithm.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.DefaultPowerMethodTolerance
member.summary: Gets and sets the default value for the tolerance used to determine convergence of the power method for computing dominant eigenvectors and eigenvalues needed by the SIMPLS algorithm.

member.summary: Whether the most recent calculation was successful.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.ResponseMean
member.summary: Gets the vector of means for the response variables.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.Coefficients
member.summary: Gets the regression coefficients matrix, B, for the PLS2 calculation. B satisifies the relationship ResponseVector = XB + E where X and ResponseVector are, respectively, the centered independent and dependent variables values, and E is a noise term for the model.
member.remarks:
The coeffient matrix, B, can be used for prediction as follows:
Let yhat(z) be the predicted value for the independet variable value z, xbar the mean of the PredictorMatrix variables and ybar the mean of ResponseVector variables. Then yhat(z) = ybar + (z - xbar)B

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.PredictorLoadings
member.summary: Gets the matrix of predictor loadings. The matrix of predictor loadings, P, is defined by P = X'T where X' is the transpose of the predictor matrix and T is the predictor score matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.ResponseLoadings
member.summary: Gets the matrix of response loadings. The matrix of response loadings, Q, is defined by Q = Y'T where Y' is the transpose of the response matrix and T is the predictor score matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.ResponseScores
member.summary: Gets the matrix of response scores.
member.remarks: The response scores matrix is described in the class summary.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PLS2SimplsAlgorithm.MaxIterations
member.summary: Gets and sets the maximum number of iterations to be performed when using the iterative power method to find dominant eigenvectors.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution
member.summary: Class PoissonDistribution represents a poisson distribution with a specified lambda, which is both the mean and the variance of the distribution. The poisson distribution a discrete distribution representing the probability of obtaining exactly n successes in N trials.
member.remarks: The Poisson Distribution is often used as a model for the number of events in a specific time period. The distribution function for the Poisson distribution is: f(x) = exp(-1*lambda) lambda^x / x! Poisson (1837) showed that the Poisson distribution is the limiting case of a binomial distribution where N approaches infinity and p goes to zero while Np = lambda.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a PoissonDistribution with the specified lambda, which is both the mean and the variance of the distribution.
member.exception: Thrown if lambda is less than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.Mean
member.summary: Gets and sets the mean of the distribution.
member.exception: Thrown if the mean is less than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.Variance
member.summary: Gets and sets the variance of the distribution.
member.remarks: The variance of the distribution is the standard deviation squared.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.Skewness
member.summary: Gets the skewness, a measure of the degree of asymmetry of this distribution.
member.remarks: The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.Kurtosis
member.summary: Gets the kurtosis, a measure of the degree of peakednesss of the distribution.
member.remarks: The kurtosis is the fourth centeral moment divided by the fouth power of the standard deviation normalized so that the kurtosis if the normal distribution is zero.

member.summary: Returns the probability density function evaluated at a given value.
member.returns: The probability density function evaluated at x.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.CDF(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the cumulative distribution function evaluated at a given value.
member.returns: The cumulative distribution function evaluated at x.
member.remarks: The value of the cumulative distribution function at a point x is the probability that the value of a random variable having this Poisson distribution is less than or equal to x.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.PoissonDistribution.InverseCDF(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse cumulative distribution function evaluated at a given value.
member.returns: The value x such that the cumulative distribution function evaluated at x yields p.
member.remarks: If p is greater than 1 or less than zero, returns Double.NaN (Not a Number).

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation
member.summary: Class QRRegressionCalculation computes linear regression parameters by the method of least squares using a QR decomposition.
member.remarks: Class QRRegressionCalculation finds the minimal norm solution to the overdetermined linear system: Ax = b That is, this class finds the vector x that minimizes the 2-norm of the residual vector Ax - b. Prerequisites on the matrix A are that it has more rows than columns, and is of full rank.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.#ctor
member.summary: Constrcts a QRRegressionCalculation instance with all sizes equal to zero.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Constructs a QRRegressionCalculation instance from the given matrix.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a QRRegressionCalculation instance from the given matrix. The specified tolerance is used in computing the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.param: Tolerance for computing the numerical rank of the matrix A. If A = QR is the QR factorization of A, then elements on the main diagonal of R are considered to be zero if their absolute value is less than or equal to tolerance.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Rows
member.summary: Gets the number of rows in the matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Cols
member.summary: Gets the number of columns in the matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.RankAvailable
member.summary: Returns the rank if it was calculated as a byproduct of the parameter calculation.
member.remarks: For instances of QRRegressionCalculation, this is always true.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Rank
member.summary: Gets the numerical rank of the matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.IsGood
member.summary: Returns true if the QR decomposition may be used to solve least squares problems; otherwise false.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Tolerance
member.summary: Gets and sets the tolerance used for computing the numerical rank of the regression matrix.
member.remarks: If A = QR is the QR factorization of A, then elements on the main diagonal of R are considered to be zero if their absolute value is less than or equal to Tolerance.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.XTXInvAvailable
member.summary: Gets a boolean value indicating whether or not the matrix formed by taking the inverse of the product of the transpose of the regression matrix with itself is available.
member.remarks: If X is the regression matrix and ' denotes matrix transposition, then this property is true if this calculation object can return the inverse of the matrix X'X.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.XTXInv
member.summary: Gets the matrix formed by taking the inverse of the product of the transpose of the regression matrix with itself, if available.
member.exception: Thrown if this object does not implmenent this calculation. This may be checked with the XTXInvAvailable property.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Factor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Factors a given matrix so that it may be used to solve least squares problems. The specified tolerance is used in computing the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.param: Tolerance for computing the numerical rank of the matrix A. If A = QR is the QR factorization of A, then elements on the main diagonal of R are considered to be zero if their absolute value is less than or equal to tolerance.
If true, the matrix A is guaranteed to contain no NaN or Infinity values.
member.remarks: For the QR least squares method to succeed, the matrix A must have full rank.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Factor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,System.Double)
member.summary: Factors a given matrix so that it may be used to solve least squares problems. The specified tolerance is used in computing the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.param: Tolerance for computing the numerical rank of the matrix A. If A = QR is the QR factorization of A, then elements on the main diagonal of R are considered to be zero if their absolute value is less than or equal to tolerance.
member.remarks: For the QR least squares method to succeed, the matrix A must have full rank.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.QRRegressionCalculation.Factor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Factors a given matrix so that it may be used to solve least squares problems.
member.remarks: For the QR least squares method to succeed, the matrix A must have full rank.

member.summary: Computes the solution to the least squares problem Ax = b.
member.param: The right-hand side of the equation.
member.returns: The solution x that minimizes the 2-norm of the residual vector Ax - b.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the vector b is not equal to the number of rows.

member.summary: Computes and returns the residual vector.
member.param: The right-hand side of the least squares problem Ax = b.
member.returns: The residual vector Ax - b, where x is the computed least squares solution to the problem Ax = b.

member.summary: Computes the 2-norm squared of the residual vector.

member.returns: The 2-norm squared of the residual vector Ax - b.

member.summary: Default constructor.

member.summary: Copy constructor.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.Parameters
member.summary: Gets the computed model parameters.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.RegressionMatrix
member.summary: Gets the regression matrix.
member.remarks:
The regression matrix is the predictor matrix (the matrix of values of the independent variables in a regression model), plus a column of leading ones, if the model contains an intercept parameter.
If you modify the data in the regression matrix using this reference, invoke the member function RecalculateParameters() to recalculate the parameters.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.PredictorMatrix
member.summary: Gets the predictor matrix.
member.remarks:
The predictor matrix is the matrix of values of the independent variables in a regression model. If the model contains an intercept parameter, then the predictor matrix is obtained from the regression matrix by removing the leading column of ones. If the model does not have an intercept parameter, then the predictor matrix is the same as the regression matrix.
If you modify the data in the predictor matrix using this reference, invoke the member function RecalculateParameters() to recalculate the parameters.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.Observations
member.summary: Gets the vector of observations.
member.remarks: If you modify the data in the observation vector using this reference, invoke the member function RecalculateParameters() to recalculate the parameters.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.NumberOfPredictors
member.summary: Gets the number of predictors.
member.remarks: If the model contains an intercept parameter, then the number of predictors is equal to the number of parameters minus one. If the model does not contain an intercept parameter, then the number of predictors is equal to the number of parameters.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.NumberOfParameters
member.summary: Gets the number of parameters in the model.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.NumberOfObservations
member.summary: Gets the number of observations.
member.remarks: This is the same as the number of rows in the regression matrix and the length of the observation vector.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.RowResizeIncrement
member.summary: Gets and sets the amount by which the regression matrix is resized if rows are added.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.ColumnResizeIncrement
member.summary: Gets and sets the amount by which the regression matrix is resized if columns are added.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.HasInterceptParameter
member.summary: Returns true if the model has an intercept parameter; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.IsGood
member.summary: Returns true if the model parameters were successfuly computed; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Gets the error message associated with a failed parameter calculation.
member.remarks: If the IsGood property is false, then the ParameterCalculationErrorMessage property contains any error message produced by the regression calculation object.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.Intercept
member.summary: Gets the intercept.
member.remarks: Returns zero if there is no intercept.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.RecalculateParameters
member.summary: Recalculates the model parameters.

member.summary: Adds a predictor to the model, and recalculates the model parameters.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the given vector is not equal to the number of rows in the regression matrix (also equal to length of the observation vector).

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.AddPredictors(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Adds predictors to the model, and recalculates the model parameters.

member.exception: Thrown if the number of rows in the given matrix is not equal to the number of rows in the regression matrix (also equal to length of the observation vector).

member.summary: Adds an intercept parameter to the model and recalculates the model parameters.
member.remarks: If the model already has an intercept parameter, this function has no effect.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.RemovePredictor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the specified predictor from the model, and recalculates the model parameters.
member.param: The index of the predictor to remove.
member.remarks: Indexing starts at 0. If the model has an intercept parameter, removing the 0th predictor will not remove the intercept parameter. Instead, use the RemoveInterceptParameter() method to remove the intercept parameter.
member.exception: Thrown if the specified index is invalid.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.RemovePredictors(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the specified predictors from the model, and recalculates the model parameters.
member.param: The total number of predictors to remove.
member.remarks: Indexing starts at 0. If the model has an intercept parameter, removing the 0th predictor will not remove the intercept parameter. Instead, use the RemoveInterceptParameter() method to remove the intercept parameter.
member.example: If startIndex = 1 and numberToRemove = 3, then the second, third, and fourth predictors are removed.
member.exception: Thrown if the specified index range is invalid.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.RemoveInterceptParameter
member.summary: Removes the intercept parameter from the model, and recalculates the model parameters.
member.remarks: If the model does not have an intercept parameter, this method has no effect.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.AddObservation(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,System.Double)
member.summary: Adds the given observation to the model, and recalculates the model parameters.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the predictor vector is not equal to the number of predictors in the model, as indicated by the NumberOfPredictors property.
member.remarks: If the model has an intercept parameter, do not include the leading one in the predictor vector. It is accounted for in the model.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.RegressionBase.AddObservations(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector)
member.summary: Adds the given observations to the model, and recalculates the model parameters.
member.param: A matrix of predictor values where each row constitutes a set of values for the predictor variables.
member.exception: Thrown if the number of columns in the predictor matrix is not equal to the number of predictors, or if the number of rows in the predictor matrix is not equal to the length of the given vector of observations.
member.remarks: If the model has an intercept parameter do not include the leading column of ones in the predictor matrix. It is accounted for in the model.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TrustRegionParameterCalc
member.summary: Parameter calculation for a logistic regression model. The parameters are computed to maximize the log likelihood function for the model, using a trust region optimization algorithm to compute the zeros of the first order partial derivaties of the log likelihood function. The minimization is performed by an instance of the class CenterSpace.NMath.Analysis.TrustRegionMinimizer and algorithms parameters may be controlled through this object. It is accessible through the Minimizer class property, and a TrustRegionParameterCalc instace may be constructed with a give TrustRegionMinimizer object which has the desired properties.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TrustRegionParameterCalc.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Analysis.TrustRegionMinimizer)
member.summary: Construct a TrustRegionParameterCalc instance which uses the give TrustRegionMinimizer instance to calculate the parameters.

member.summary: Construct a TrustRegionParameterCalc instance using default parameters for the trust region minimization algorithm.

member.summary: Construct a TrustRegionParameterCalc instance using the given tolerance to determine convergence of the trust region minimization algorithm.

member.summary: Construct a TrustRegionParameterCalc instance using the given maximum number of iterations to be performed by the trust region minimization algorithm.

member.summary: Construct a TrustRegionParameterCalc instance using the given maximum number of iterations to be performed by the trust region minimization algorithm, and the given tolerance used to determine convergence.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaTypeI
member.summary:
Class for performing a Type I ANOVA on unbalanced data. See the description of the base class TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced for a description of the notation.
Type I, also called "sequential" sum of squares: SS(A) for factor A. SS(B | A) for factor B. SS(AB | B, A) for interaction AB. This tests the main effect of factor A, followed by the main effect of factor B after the main effect of A, followed by the interaction effect AB after the main effects.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaTypeI.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.DataFrame,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a TwoWayAnovaTypeI instance from data in the given data frame.
member.param: The index of the column for Factor A.
The index of the column for Factor B.
The index of the data column. The indicated column must be numeric and cannot contain missing values.

If true sums of squares will be computed for each regression parameter. If false sums of squares will be computed only for each regression factor. So, if factor A has m levels and factor B has n levels and fullIncrementalSumOfSquares is true (m - 1) + (n - 1) + (m - 1)*(n - 1) sums of squares will be computed - one for each dummy regression parameter. if fullIncrementalSumOfSquares is false, only 3 sums of squares will be computed - one for factor A, one for factor B, and one for the interaction.
member.remarks: Factors are constructed from the factor columns using the DataFrame method GetFactor(), which creates a sorted array of the unique values.
member.exception: Thrown if the data column contains missing values (NaNs) or the data cannot be converted into numeric values.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaTypeII
member.summary:
Class for performing a Type II ANOVA on unbalanced data. See the description of the base class TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced for a description of the notation.
SS(A | B) for factor A. SS(B | A) for factor B. SS(AB | A, B) for interaction. This type tests for each main effect after the other main effect. Note that no significant interaction is assumed and you should look look at the test for interaction first (SS(AB | A, B)) and only if interaction after the main effects AB is not significant continue with the analysis for main effects.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaTypeII.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.DataFrame,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a TwoWayAnovaTypeI instance from data in the given data frame.
member.param: The index of the column for Factor A.
The index of the column for Factor B.
The index of the data column. The indicated column must be numeric and cannot contain missing values.

If true sums of squares will be computed for each regression parameter. If false sums of squares will be computed only for each regression factor. So, if factor A has m levels and factor B has n levels and fullIncrementalSumOfSquares is true (m - 1) + (n - 1) + (m - 1)*(n - 1) sums of squares will be computed - one for each dummy regression parameter. if fullIncrementalSumOfSquares is false, only 3 sums of squares will be computed - one for factor A, one for factor B, and one for the interaction.
member.remarks: Factors are constructed from the factor columns using the DataFrame method GetFactor(), which creates a sorted array of the unique values.
member.exception: Thrown if the data column contains missing values (NaNs) or the data cannot be converted into numeric values.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaTypeIII
member.summary:
Class for performing a Type III ANOVA on unbalanced data. See the description of the base class TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced for a description of the notation.
SS(A | B, AB) for factor A. SS(B | A, AB) for factor B. SS(AB | A, B) for interaction. This type tests for the presence of a main effect after the other main effect and interaction. This approach is therefore valid in the presence of significant interactions. However, it is often not interesting to interpret a main effect if interactions are present (generally speaking, if a significant interaction is present, the main effects should not be further analysed).

member.param: The index of the column for Factor A.

member.remarks: Factors are constructed from the factor columns using the DataFrame method GetFactor(), which creates a sorted array of the unique values.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced
member.summary:
Class TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced is the base class for performing a two way ANOVA when the number of observations in each cell is not the same (an unbalanced design). In this case the main and interaction effects are interdependent, and we must obtain the marginal sum of squares associated with each factor after all the other factors have already been included in the model (the marginal sum of squares for each variable equals the incremental sum of squares for that variable when it is entered into the equation last). In terms of a regression approach to ANOVA, the marginal sum of squares due to a factor is the sum of squares for the set of dummy variables associated with that factor when those dummy variables are entered into the model last, after all other dummy variables.
Classes deriving from TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced provide the ordering of dummy regression variables and use the base class to compute the resulting regressions and sums of squares.
member.remarks: We will use the notion described by Scholer. http://goanna.cs.rmit.edu.au/~fscholer/anova.php" What follows is an excerpt. Consider a model that includes two factors A and B; there are therefore two main effects, and an interaction, AB. The full model is represented by SS(A, B, AB). Other models are represented similarly: SS(A, B) indicates the model with no interaction, SS(B, AB) indicates the model that does not account for effects from factor A, and so on. It is convenient to define incremental sums of squares to represent these differences. Let SS(AB | A, B) = SS(A, B, AB) - SS(A, B) SS(A | B, AB) = SS(A, B, AB) - SS(B, AB) SS(B | A, AB) = SS(A, B, AB) - SS(A, AB) SS(A | B) = SS(A, B) - SS(B) SS(B | A) = SS(A, B) - SS(A) The notation shows the incremental differences in sums of squares, for example SS(AB | A, B) represents "the sum of squares for interaction after the main effects", and SS(A | B) is "the sum of squares for the A main effect after the B main effect and ignoring interactions"

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaUnbalanced.ParameterSlices
member.summary:
As long as the dummy regression parameters are the same, we may use the same regression matrix to compute the various marginal sums of squares. Since the dummy variables for a given factor, or the interaction parameters, will always be contiguous columns in the regression matrix, their location can be specified with slices. The ParameterSlices class specifies the slices where factor A, factor B, and interaction dummy variables are located in the regression matrix.
The following terminology is used throughout: Regression matrix - the matrix of regression parameters include the intercept parameter, which is expressed as a leading column of 1's in the matrix.
Predictor matrix - The matrix of regression parameters excluding the intercept parameter.
Thus regression parameters start at column 1 in the regression matrix and column 0 in the predictor matrix.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaUnbalancedTable
member.summary: Class TwoWayAnovaUnbalancedTable summarizes the information of a traditional two-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) table.
member.remarks: Class TwoWayAnovaUnbalancedTable derives from class DataFrame in order to represent a traditional two-way ANOVA table. A two-way ANOVA table contains 5 rows and 6 columns. The rows contain information for each of the following sources: Factor A, Factor B, the Interaction between Factor A and Factor B, Error (Residual), and Total. The columns contain the following quantities for each source: Degrees of Freedom, Sum of Squares, Mean Square, F statistice and P-values (only for the Factors A and B and their interaction).

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions
member.summary: Class StatsFunctions provides statistical functions for NMath types, including descriptive statistics and special functions.
member.remarks:
Class StatsFunctions provides a wide variety of static functions for computing descriptive statistics, such as mean, variance, standard deviation, percentile, median, quartiles, geometric mean, harmonic mean, RMS, kurtosis, skewness, and many more.
Method overloads accept data as an array of doubles, an array of integers, a DoubleVector, or as a numeric column in a DataFrame.
Most functions in class StatsFunctions are accompanied by a paired function which ignores values that are Not-a-Number (NaN). For example, there are Mean() and NaNMean() functions, Variance() and NaNVariance() functions, and so forth. Unless a function is explicitly designed to handle missing values, it may return NaN or have unexpected results if values are missing. The provided convenience method NaNCheck() returns true if a given data set contains any missing values.
Class StatsFunctions also provides some special functions, including combinatorial functions, the gamma function, and the beta function.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.IncompleteBeta(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the value of the incomplete beta function at a given value.
member.remarks: The incomplete beta function is a generalization of the beta function.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.Beta(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the value of the beta function at a given value.
member.remarks: The beta function is related to the gamma function as follows: B(z,w) = ( Gamma(z) * Gamma(w) ) / Gamma(z + w)

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.IncompleteGamma(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the incomplete gamma function at a given value.
member.param: A parameter describing the incomplete gamma function.
member.returns: The integral from x to infinity of (t^(a-1) * e^-t)dt.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.IncompleteGammaComplement(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the complement of the incomplete gamma function, P(a,x), at a given value. The complement of the incomplete gamma function P(a,x) is defined to be 1.0 - P(a,x)
member.param: A parameter describing the incomplete gamma function.
member.returns: The integral from x to infinity of (t^(a-1) * e^-t)dt.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.IncompleteGamma(System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the incomplete gamma function P(a,x) or its complement 1.0 - P(a,x) for for the parameter a and value x.
member.param: A parameter describing the incomplete gamma function.
If true the complement, 1.0 - P(a,x) will be computed. otherwise P(a,x) will be computed.
member.returns: The integral from x to infinity of (t^(a-1) * e^-t)dt.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns n!, the number of ways that n objects can be permuted.
member.exception: Thrown if n is not positive.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.FactorialLn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the natural log factorial of n, ln( n! ).
member.exception: Thrown if n is not positive.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.Binomial(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the binomial coefficient ("n choose m"), the number of ways of picking m unordered outcomes from n possibilities.
member.remarks:
The binomial coefficient nCm ("n choose m") is defined by:
nCm = n! / ( m! ( n - m )! )

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.BinomialLn(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the natural log of the binomial coefficient ("n choose m"), the number of ways of picking m unordered outcomes from n possibilities.
member.returns: The natural log of the binomial coefficient.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.CentralMoment(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the specified central moment about the mean for the the given data.
member.exception: Thrown if data has a length of zero.
member.remarks: The first central moment is equal to zero. The second central moment is the variance. The third central moment is the skewness. The fourth central moment is the kurtosis.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.CentralMoment(System.Double[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the specified central moment about the mean for the the given data.
member.exception: Thrown if data has a length of zero.
member.remarks: The first central moment is equal to zero. The second central moment is the variance. The third central moment is the skewness. The fourth central moment is the kurtosis.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.CorrelationMatrix(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Computes the Pearson correlation matrix for a set of random inputs. The random inputs are taken to be the columns of the input matrix. The symmetric, positive definite matrix whose i,j entry is the Pearson correlation coefficient between the inputs in column i and column j is computed and returned.
member.remarks: A constant column (and therefore standard deviation of zero) leads to a correlation of zero.
member.param: Matrix whose columns are the inputs whose Spearman rank correlation coefficient is computed.
member.returns: The symmetric, positive definite matrix whose row i, column j entry is the correlation coefficient between the inputs in column i and column j

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.CovarianceMatrix(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.FloatMatrix)
member.summary: Creates a square, symmetric matrix containing the variances and covariances of the columns in data.
member.remarks: If C is the returned covariance matrix, then the diagonal elements C[i,i] represent the variances for the columns of data. The off-diagonal elements C[i,j] represent the covariances of columns i and j. Uses the default bias in StatsSettings.
member.exception: Thrown if data has only one row.

member.param: Memoize intermediate calculations. Improve performance at the cost of using more memory

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.FishersExactTest(CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.DataFrame)
member.summary: Returns the one-tailed Fisher's Exact Test p-value for the specified 2 x 2 contingency table and alternative hypothesis.
member.returns: The lesser of the right and left tail p-value.
member.remarks:
Fisher's exact test is so-called because the significance of the deviation from a null hypothesis can be calculated exactly, rather than relying on an approximation.
Fisher's exact test is a useful alternative to the chi-square test in cases where sample sizes are small. The usual rule of thumb for deciding whether the chi-squared approximation is good enough is whether the expected values in all cells of the contingency table is greater than or equal to 5.
member.exception: Thrown if the dimensions of the given contigency table are not 2 x 2, if both columns are not instances of DFIntColumn, or if any of the count values is negative.

member.summary: Returns the Fisher's Exact Test p-value for the specified 2 x 2 contingency table and alternative hypothesis.
member.param: Enum value indicating the form of the alternative hypothesis.
member.remarks:
Fisher's exact test is so-called because the significance of the deviation from a null hypothesis can be calculated exactly, rather than relying on an approximation.
Fisher's exact test is a useful alternative to the chi-square test in cases where sample sizes are small. The usual rule of thumb for deciding whether the chi-squared approximation is good enough is whether the expected values in all cells of the contingency table is greater than or equal to 5.
member.exception: Thrown if the dimensions of the given contigency table are not 2 x 2, if both columns are not instances of DFIntColumn, or if any of the count values is negative.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.WeightedMedian(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector)
member.summary: Returns the weighted median of an array of data with associated non-negative weights. There must be at least one postive non-zero weight.
member.param: An DoubleVector containing the non-negative weights.
member.remarks: If the lower sum of the weights is equal the weight's midpoint, then the average of the adjacent two datapoints is returned.
member.exception: The two lengths of the data and weights vectors must be equal.
There must be at least one postive non-zero weight.
All weights must be non-negative. At least one negative weight was found.

member.remarks: If the lower sum of the weights is equal the weight's midpoint, then the average of the adjacent two datapoints is returned.
member.exception: The two lengths of the data and weights vectors must be equal.
There must be at least one postive non-zero weight.
All weights must be non-negative. At least one negative weight was found.

member.summary: Calculates the weighted variance of the given data.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.WeightedVariance(CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.IDFColumn,CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.IDFColumn)
member.summary: Calculates the weighted variance of the given data.
member.exception: Thrown if data and weights do not have the same length.
Thrown if data or weights are not numeric.
member.remarks: If weights is an IDFIntColumn, the weights are interpreted as frequency counts, which in effect expand the data by these counts, so no normalization is performed. Otherwise, the weights are interpreted as sampling (reliability) weights and the weight values are normalized to sum to the length of the data column.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.InitialCenters(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,System.Int32)
member.summary: Chooses the specified number of initial centers from the given data matrix, for clustering algorithms such as k-means.
member.param: A matrix of data. Each row in the matrix represents an object to be clustered.
The number of initial cluster centers.
member.exception: Thrown if the number of cluster centers is less than one or greater than the number of data points (data.Rows).
member.remarks: Uses the following algorithm: If the distance between row r and its closest center is greater than the distance between the two closest centers (m, n), then r replaces m or n, whichever is closest to r. Otherwise, if the distance between row r and its closest center (q) is greater than the distance between q and its closest center, then row r replaces q. (Similar to SPSS QuickCluster function.)

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.VanDerWaerdenScores(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a vector of Van Der Waerden scores. Van der Waerden scores are the quantiles of a standard normal distribution. These scores are also known as quantile normal scores.
member.param: The number of scores to produce.
member.returns: A vector containing n Van Der Waerden scores.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.VanDerWaerdenScores(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a vector of Van Der Waerden scores. Van der Waerden scores are the quantiles of a standard normal distribution. These scores are also known as quantile normal scores. The scores are computed from the standard normal distribution with mean 0 and variance 1.
member.param: The number of scores to produce.
member.returns: A vector containing n Van Der Waerden scores.

member.summary: Creates two sequences of correlated random numbers using the specified random number generators. The created sequence's Spearman rank correlation will be approximately equal to the specified number.
member.param: The number of correlated random numbers to createn
The desired Spearman rank correlation for the the two sequnces. Must be between -1 and 1, inclusive.
Random number generator for one of the sequences.
Random number generator for the other sequence.
member.returns: Matrix whose columns are the two sequences of correlated random numbers.
member.exception: Thrown if desired rank correlation is not between -1 and 1.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.CorrelatedRandomInputs(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,CenterSpace.NMath.Matrix.DoubleSymmetricMatrix)
member.summary: Accepts a set of input varaibles, each stored as a row in a matrix, and constructs a corresponding matrix of input variable values whose Spearmans rank correlation matrix is approximately equal to the specified correlation matrix. The resulting correlated inputs marginal distributions are the same as the original inputs.
member.param: Inputs to be transformed to correlated inputs with approximately the specified rank correlation matrix. Each row of the matrix represents an input variable value.
A symmetric matrix containing the desired rank correlation matrix.
member.returns: A matrix containing the input variable values rearranged so that their rank correlation matrix is approximately equal to the desiredCorrelations

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.StatsFunctions.CorrelatedRandomInputs(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Accepts a set of input varaibles, each stored as a row in a matrix, and constructs a corresponding matrix of input variable values whose Spearmans rank correlation matrix is approximately equal to the specified correlation matrix. The resulting correlated inputs with their marginal distributions intact.
member.param: Inputs to be transformed to correlated inputs with approximately the specified rank correlation matrix. Each row of the matrix represents an input variable value.
A matrix containing the desired rank correlation matrix.
member.returns: A matrix containing the input variable values rearranged so that their rank correlation matrix is approximately equal to the desiredCorrelations

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.Subset
member.summary: Class Subset represents a collection of indices that can be used to view a subset of data from another data structure.
member.remarks: Unlike a Slice or a Range, a Subset need not be continuous, or even ordered. It is simply an arbitrary collection of indices.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation
member.summary: Class SVDRegressionCalculation computes linear regression parameters by the method of least squares using a singular value decomposition.
member.remarks: Class SVDRegressionCalculation finds the minimal norm solution to the overdetermined linear system: Ax = b That is, this class finds the vector x that minimizes the 2-norm of the residual vector Ax - b.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an SVDRegressionCalculation instance with all sizes equal to zero.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Constructs an SVDRegressionCalculation instance from the given matrix.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a SVDRegressionCalculation instance from the given matrix. The specified tolerance is used in computing the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.param: Tolerance for computing the numerical rank of the matrix A. All singular values of the matrix less than tolerance are set to zero.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Rows
member.summary: Gets the number of rows in the matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Cols
member.summary: Gets the number of columns in the matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.RankAvailable
member.summary: Returns the rank if it was calculated as a byproduct of the parameter calculation.
member.remarks: For instances of QRRegressionCalculation, this is always true.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Rank
member.summary: Gets the numerical rank of the matrix.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.XTXInvAvailable
member.summary: Gets a boolean indicating whether or not the matrix formed by taking the inverse of the product of the transpose of the regression matrix with itself is avaialble as part of the decomposition.
member.remarks: If X is the regression matrix and ' denotes matrix transposition, then this property is true if this calculation object can return the inverse of the matrix X'X.
For instances of QRRegressionCalculation, this is always true.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.XTXInv
member.summary: Gets the matrix formed by taking the inverse of the product of the transpose of the regression matrix with itself, if available.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.IsGood
member.summary: Returns true if the singular value decomposition may be used to solve least squares problems; otherwise false.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Tolerance
member.summary: Gets and sets the tolerance for computing the numerical rank and SVD tuncation. In truncation all singular values less than Tolerance are set to zero and solutions will be computed using the truncated SVD. If the Tolerance is set to 0 no truncation will be performed. The default tolerance is 0, i.e. no truncation.
member.remarks: Truncation is only useful if your predictor matrix has less than full rank.

members.member:
Gets the status of the singular value decomposition.
Returns true if the decomposition algorithm failed to converge; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Factor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,System.Double)
member.summary: Factors a given matrix so that it may be used to solve least squares problems. The specified tolerance is used in computing the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.param: Tolerance for computing the numerical rank of the matrix A. All singular values of the matrix A less than tolerance are set to zero.
member.remarks: For the SVD least squares method to succeed, the matrix A must have full rank.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Factor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary: Factors a given matrix so that it may be used to solve least squares problems.
member.remarks: For the SVD least squares method to succeed, the matrix A must have full rank.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.Solve(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector)
member.summary: Computes the solution to the least squares problem Ax = b.
member.param: The right-hand side of the equation.
member.returns: The solution x that minimizes the 2-norm of the residual vector Ax - b.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the vector b is not equal to the number of rows.
member.remarks: If a tolerance for the SVD calculation was specified the solution will be computed using the truncated SVD.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.CalculateParameters(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the parameters for the regression using a singular value decomposition of the regression matrix to solve the least squares problem.
member.param: If true, the regression matrix is guaranteed to contain no NaN or Infinity values.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the observation vector is not equal to the number of rows in the regression matrix.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.SVDRegressionCalculation.CalculateParameters(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector)
member.summary: Calculates the parameters for the regression using a singular value decomposition of the regression matrix to solve the least squares problem.
member.exception: Thrown if the length of the observation vector is not equal to the number of rows in the regression matrix.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution
member.summary: Class TDistribution represents Student's t-distribution with the specified degrees of freedom.
member.remarks: As the number of degrees of freedom grows, the t-distribution approaches the normal distribution with mean 0 and variance 1.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a TDistribution instance with the given degrees of freedom.
member.param: The degrees of freedom for the distribution.
member.exception: Thrown if the specified degrees of freedom is less than or equal to zero.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor. Constructs a TDistribution instance with one degree of freedom.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.DegreesOfFreedom
member.summary: Gets and sets the degrees of freedom for the distribution.
member.exception: Thrown if set to a value less than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.Mean
member.summary: Gets the mean of the distribution.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.Variance
member.summary: Gets the variance of the distribution.
member.remarks: The variance of the distribution is the standard deviation squared. If the degrees of freedom for the distribution is less than 3, the variance is undefined. In this case Double.NaN is returned.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.Skewness
member.summary: Gets the skewness, a measure of the degree of asymmetry of this distribution.
member.remarks: The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation. If the degrees of freedom for the distribution is less than 4, the skewness is undefined. However, the distribution is symmetric in all cases so zero is returned in all cases.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.Kurtosis
member.summary: Gets the kurtosis, a measure of the degree of peakednesss of the distribution.
member.remarks: The kurtosis is the fourth centeral moment divided by the fouth power of the standard deviation normalized so that the kurtosis if the normal distribution is zero. If the degrees of freedom for the distribution is less than 5, the skewness is undefined. In this case Double.NaN is returned.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.PDF(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the probability density function evaluated at a given value.
member.param: The value at which to evaluate the probability density function.
member.returns: The probability density function evaluated at x.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.CDF(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the cumulative density function evaluated at the given value.
member.param: The value at which to evaluate the cumulative density function.
member.returns: The cumulative density function evaluated at z.
member.remarks: The value of the cumulative density function at a point z is probability that the value of a random variable having this normal density is less than or equal to z.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.InverseCDF(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse cumulative density function evaluated at the given value.
member.returns: The value x such that the cumulative density function evaluated at x yields p.
member.remarks: If p is greater than 1 or less than zero, Double.NaN (Not a Number) is returned.

member.summary: Creates a deep copy of this TDistribution.
member.returns: A deep copy of this TDistribution.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TDistribution.ToString
member.summary: Returns a formatted string representation of this distribution.
member.returns: A formatted string representation of this distribution.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TriangularDistribution
member.summary: Class TriangularDistribution represents the triangular probability distribution.
member.remarks: The triangular distribution is defined by three parameters, a lower limit a, an upper limit b, and number c, between a and b, called the mode. the probability density function (PDF) has the shape of a triangle in the X/Y plane with verices (a, 0), (b, 0), and (c, y), where y is chosen so that the area of the triangle is 1.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TriangularDistribution.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a TriangularDistribution instance with the given upper and lower limits and mode equal to their midpoint.
member.param: The lower limit of the distribution.
The upper limit of the distribution.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TriangularDistribution.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor. Constructs a TriangularDistribution with lower limit 0, upper limit 1, and mode 0.5.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TriangularDistribution.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a TriangularDistribution with the given parameters.
member.param: The upper limit of the distribution.
The lower limit of the distribution.
The mode of the distribution. Must be between the upper and lower limits.
member.exception: Thrown if the mode is less than the lower limit or greater than the upper limit.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoSampleKSTest
member.summary: Class TwoSampleKSTest performs a two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to compare the distributions of values in two data sets.
member.remarks: For each potential value x, the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test compares the proportion of values in the first sample less than x with the proportion of values in the second sample less than x. The null hypothesis is that the two samples have the same continuous distribution. The alternative hypothesis is that they have different continuous distributions.

member.exception: Thrown if data1 or data2 has length of zero, after removing missing values.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoSamplePairedTTest
member.summary: Class TwoSamplePairedTTest tests if two paired sets of observed values differ from each other in a significant way.
member.remarks: Paired samples often occur in pre-test/post-test studies in which subjects are measured before and after an intervention. They also occur in matched-pairs (for example, matching on age and sex), cross-over trials, and sequential observational samples. Paired samples are also called matched samples and dependent samples.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoSamplePairedTTest.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor. Constructs a TwoSamplePairedTTest instance with default sample parameters, alpha level, and hypothesis type.
member.remarks: Constructs a TwoSamplePairedTTest instance with a sample mean of the differences between paired observations of 0.0, sample standard deviation of the differences of 1.0, and sample size of 2. The alpha level is set to the current value specified by the static DefaultAlpha property; the form of the hypothesis test is set to the current DefaultType.

The standard deviation of the differences between paired observations.
member.remarks: The alpha level is set to the current value specified by the static DefaultAlpha property; the form of the hypothesis test is set to the current DefaultType.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.WilcoxonSignedRankTest
member.summary: Class WilcoxonSignedRankTest tests if two paired sets of observed values differ from each other in a significant way.
member.remarks:
The Wilcoxon signed-rank is a non-parametric statistical hypothesis test for comparing the means between two paired samples, or repeated measurements on a single sample. It can be used as an alternative to TwoSamplePairedTTest when the population cannot be assumed to be normally distributed.
The null hypothesis is that the distribution x - y is symmetric about 0.
For n > 10, the sampling distribution of the test statistic converges to a normal distribution. For smaller sample sizes, an exact p-value can be calculated by enumerating all possible combinations of the test statistic given n.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.WilcoxonSignedRankTest.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector)
member.summary: Constructs a WilcoxonSignedRankTest instance using the given paired vectors of sample data.
member.remarks:
Paired observations where either value is missing, or where the difference between values is zero, are ignored.
The alpha level is set to the current value specified by the static DefaultAlpha property. The form of the hypothesis test is set to the current DefaultType. Whether an asymptotic p-value or an exact p-value is calculated is determined by the current DefaultExactPValue.
member.exception: Thrown if the given data contains zero valid pairs (valid pairs are non-NaN and unequal), or if DefaultExactPvalue equals true for n > 30;

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.WilcoxonSignedRankTest.#ctor(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleVector,System.Double,CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.HypothesisType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a WilcoxonSignedRankTest instance using the given paired vectors of sample data, and the given hypothesis parameters.
member.param: The accepted probability of falsely rejecting the null hypothesis.
Enum value indicating the form of the alternative hypothesis.
A boolean value indicating whether to calculate an exact p-value by enumerating all possible combinations of the test statistic given n. If false, a normal approximation is used.
member.remarks: Paired observations where either value is missing, or where the difference between values is zero, are ignored.
member.exception: Thrown if the given data contains zero valid pairs (valid pairs are non-NaN and unequal), or if exactPvalue equals true for n > 30;

member.exception: Thrown if the given data contains zero valid pairs (valid pairs are non-NaN and unequal), or if DefaultExactPvalue equals true for n > 30;

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.WilcoxonSignedRankTest.ComputeExactPValue(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes an exact p-value by enumerating all possible rank sums.
member.remarks:
All 2^n possible distributions of signs over ranks are generated as bit-patterns. The algorithm is adapted from http://www.fon.hum.uva.nl/Service/Statistics/Signed_Rank_Algorihms.html#C.
Equivalent to the R psignrank() method.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoSampleUnpairedTTest
member.summary: Class TwoSampleUnpairedTTest tests the null hypothesis that the two population means corresponding to two random samples are equal.
member.remarks: The two samples are assumed to be independent of each other. (For dependent, or paired, samples, see class TwoSamplePairedTTest.) The samples are also assumed to come from populations with the same variance, allowing for a pooled estimate of the variance.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoSampleUnpairedTTest.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor. Constructs a TwoSampleUnpairedTTest instance with default sample parameters, alpha level, and hypothesis type.
member.remarks: Constructs a TwoSampleUnpairedTTest instance with a sample means of 0.0, sample standard deviations of 1.0, and sample sizes of 2. The alpha level is set to the current value specified by the static DefaultAlpha property; the form of the hypothesis test is set to the current DefaultType.

member.summary: Gets the array of estimates for the linear regression parameters corresponding to the dummy variables for the different factor levels.

member.summary: Gets the array of estimates for the linear regression parameters corresponding to the dummy variables for the interactions.

member.summary: Gets the intercept parameter from the linear regression that was used to compute the ANOVA.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnova.GetRegressionFactorParameter(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the regression parameter associated with the specified factor level.
member.remarks: To construct the linear regression used to compute the two way ANOVA, the effects encoding method is used for the dummy regression variables. This means that if a factor has n different levels there are n-1 dummy variables corresponding to that factor. Hence, one level does not have a dummy variable associated with it in the linear regression, and a null reference may be returned even though a valid factor level is specified.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnova.GetRegressionInteractionParameter(System.String,System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the regression parameter associated with the specified interaction.
member.param: The name of the first factor.
The level for the first factor.
The name of the second factor.
The level for the second factor.
member.remarks: To construct the linear regression used to compute the two way ANOVA, the effects encoding method is used for the dummy regression variables. This means that if there are n different levels for the first factor and m different levels for the second factor, there are (n-1) * (m-1) dummy variables corresponding to the interactions. Hence, some interactions do have a dummy variable associated with them in the linear regression, and a null reference may be returned even though valid interactions are specified.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayAnovaTable
member.summary: Class TwoWayAnovaTable summarizes the information of a traditional two-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) table.
member.remarks:
Class TwoWayAnovaTable derives from class DataFrame in order to represent a traditional two-way ANOVA table. A two-way ANOVA table contains 5 rows and 6 columns. The rows contain information for each of the following sources: Factor A, Factor B, the Interaction between Factor A and Factor B, Error (Residual), and Total. The columns contain the following quantities for each source: Degrees of Freedom, Sum of Squares, Mean Square, F statistice and P-values (only for the Factors A and B and their interaction).
Instances of TwoWayAnovaTable are obtained from a TwoWayAnova object using the AnovaTable property, and cannot be constructed independently.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayRanova.GetRegressionFactorParameters
member.summary: Fills in the array of AnovaRegressionFactorParam objects.

member.name: M:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayRanova.FillInSubjectMatrix(CenterSpace.NMath.Core.DoubleMatrix)
member.summary:
Fills in a matrix with the values of subject dummy variables used as a part of the regression matrix for the regression that is used to compute the RANOVA. This subject matrix will have ones on the main diagonal up to, but not including the last row. The last row will be all -1. All other elements are zero. This corresponds to the following encoding of the subject dummy variables:
If there are n subjects and the ith value of the dummy variable is denoted by Si, then Si = 1, if person i and i is strictly less than n Si = -1, if person n Si = 0, otherwise.

member.name: T:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayRanovaTable
member.summary: Class TwoWayRanovaTable summarizes the information of a traditional two-way Analysis of Variance (RANOVA) table.
member.remarks:
Class TwoWayRanovaTable derives from class DataFrame in order to represent a traditional two-way RANOVA table. A two-way RANOVA table contains 6 rows and 6 columns. The rows contain information for each of the following sources: Factor A, Factor B, the Interaction between Factor A and Factor B, Subjects in the nonrepeated factor, Error (Residual), and Total. The columns contain the following quantities for each source: Degrees of Freedom, Sum of Squares, Mean Square, F statistice and P-values (only for the Factors A and B and their interaction).
Instances of TwoWayRanovaTable are obtained from a TwoWayRanova object using the RanovaTable property, and cannot be constructed independently.

member.name: F:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayRanovaTable.SubjectsRowKey
member.summary: The key used to access the Subjects row in the RANOVA table.

member.summary: Gets the sum of squares for the subjects.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayRanovaTable.SubjectsDegreesOfFreedom
member.summary: Gets the subjects degrees of freedom.

member.name: P:CenterSpace.NMath.Stats.TwoWayRanovaTable.SubjectsMeanSquare
member.summary: Gets the mean square for the subjects.

member.summary: Class TwoWayRanovaTwoTable summarizes the information of a traditional two-way Analysis of Variance, with repeated measures on both factors, table,
member.remarks:
Class TwoWayRanovaTwoTable derives from class DataFrame in order to represent a traditional two-way RANOVA table. A two-way RANOVA table contains 7 rows and 6 columns. The rows contain information for each of the following sources: Factor A, Factor B, the Interaction between Factor A and Factor B, the Interactions between Factor A and subjects, the interaction between Factor B and subjets, Error (Residual), and Total. The columns contain the followingquantities for each source: Degrees of Freedom, Sum of Squares, Mean Square, F statistice and P-values (only for the Factors A and B and their interaction).
Instances of TwoWayRanovaTwoTable are obtained from a TwoWayRanovaTwo object using the RanovaTable property, and cannot be constructed independently.

member.remarks: The probability density function of the Weibull distribution is given by: f(x;k,a) = (k/a)*(x/a)^(k-1)*exp(-(x/a)k)
